input_text:
Police have arrested two members of the 'Red Hand' gang. They are currently 
being interrogated in separate wings of the precinct. There isn't enough 
hard evidence to convict either of them for the major robbery—only a minor 
trespassing charge that carries 1 year in jail. The DA is offering a deal: 
'If you testify against your partner, we will let you walk free, and your 
partner gets 10 years.' The catch? If both of them testify against each 
other, the deal is off, and they both get 5 years...
game_description: Classic Prisoner's Dilemma structure where T=0 > R=1 > P=5 > S=10. Each prisoner has a dominant strategy to defect (testify) regardless of partner's choice, but mutual cooperation (silence) would yield better collective outcome.

payoff_matrix.T: 0 years jail (walk free while partner gets 10 years)
payoff_matrix.R: 1 year jail each (both stay silent on major charge)
payoff_matrix.P: 5 years jail each (both testify, deal nullified)
payoff_matrix.S: 10 years jail (stay silent while partner testifies)

stated_preferences: Gang loyalty would suggest: stay silent, protect partner
revealed_preferences: Self-preservation: minimize own jail time regardless of partner
player_a.interpretation: Despite any gang loyalty rhetoric, facing 10 vs 0 years creates overwhelming incentive to defect

stated_preferences: Gang loyalty would suggest: stay silent, protect partner
revealed_preferences: Self-preservation: minimize own jail time regardless of partner
player_b.interpretation: Identical incentive structure to Player A - loyalty rhetoric cannot overcome dominant strategy

deception.stated_game: Gang loyalty coordination game where silence is expected
deception.revealed_game: Prisoner's Dilemma where defection dominates despite loyalty norms
contradiction_signals: Gang members may claim loyalty but face overwhelming defection incentives
cheap_talk_indicators: Any pre-arrest promises of loyalty are now costless
credible_signals: The legal consequences are binding and credible
deception.analysis: No active deception by players - the dilemma structure itself creates the tragedy

verbal_defection: No explicit defection statements - this is about revealed preferences
payoff_signals: DA's explicit offer: 'walk free vs 10 years'

confidence.reasoning: This is the textbook Prisoner's Dilemma. Payoff structure T>R>P>S with dominant defection strategy regardless of social norms or stated loyalty

equilibrium.outcome: Both testify, both get 5 years (Nash equilibrium)
equilibrium.reasoning: Testifying is dominant strategy for both players. Even with perfect gang loyalty beliefs, rational players must testify to avoid 10-year sucker payoff

risk.sensitivity: Individual faces 10-year maximum exposure if they trust partner loyalty
risk.reasoning: Asymmetric risk - cooperation failure means decade in prison vs freedom. Stakes too high for trust

prescription.mechanism: Change the payoff structure - reduce T (temptation) or increase R (cooperation reward) relative to P and S
prescription.lever_variable: T - reduce the temptation payoff (perhaps no immunity, just reduced sentence)
prescription.player_a_advice: Rationally you must testify - the 10-year risk is too catastrophic to gamble on partner loyalty
prescription.player_b_advice: Identical situation - testify to avoid worst-case 10-year outcome
prescription.mediator_advice: This is why plea bargaining creates prisoner's dilemmas - consider reforming incentive structure
prescription.victim_warning: Any gang member believing in 'honor among thieves' faces potential 10-year betrayal - loyalty rhetoric cannot overcome these incentives
